entry.title: Tunisia tourism lifeline may be crippled by European warnings; Arab Spring legacy threatened
entry.summary: While most European tourists appear to be abandoning Tunisia, a few are showing solidarity with the country whose revolution surprised the world and whose path to democracy remains an inspiration to many.

entry.title: Tunisia tourism may be crippled by European warnings
entry.summary: Similar stories are told up and down Tunisia's Mediterranean shore, as resort entertainers seek work elsewhere and hotel managers ponder whether and when to close down.

entry.title: Tunisia declares state of emergency after beach attack
entry.summary:
Tunisia has faced a post-revolution surge in jihadist violence in which dozens of police and soldiers have been killed.

The jihadist attacks have dealt a heavy blow to the tourism industry, which contributes between seven and eight percent of Tunisia's GDP.

An aide to Tunisia's prime minister said on Saturday that several officials, including the Sousse governor and those from the assailant's home town and where he studied, as well as police officers, had been sacked.

entry.title: Tunisia overwhelmingly passes anti-terror law
entry.summary: The report said Tunisia's police suffered from corruption, brutality and poor organization.

entry.title: Tunisia overwhelmingly passes anti-terror law
entry.summary: Outrage over the attacks, which crippled Tunisia's vital tourism industry, swept aside reservations over the anti-terror legislation.

entry.title: Tunisia overwhelmingly passes anti-terror law
entry.summary: Alone of all those countries, Tunisia has emerged with a democracy, but has since been tested by a rise in attacks by Islamic radicals.

entry.title: Tunisia overwhelmingly passes anti-terror law
entry.summary: The sole country to emerge from the 2011 uprisings with a democracy, Tunisia has been targeted by militant groups.

entry.title: Tunisia overwhelmingly passes anti-terror law
entry.summary: Tunisia's parliament has voted overwhelmingly to pass the country's new anti-terror law despite fears by rights groups that it could be abused.

entry.title: Tunisia police kill militant and arrest 13 others
Tunisia police kill suspected militant and arrest 13 others
entry.summary: One suspected militant has been killed and 13 others arrested in a late-night operation that foiled a planned attack in Tunisia.

entry.title: EU Agrees to Help Tunisia Fight Terror, Boost Economy
entry.summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, right, welcomes Tunisia's Prime Minister Habib Essid upon his arrival at EU headquarters in Brussels on Monday, July 20, 2015.

entry.title: EU agrees to help Tunisia fight terror, boost economy
entry.summary: BRUSSELS (AP) " The European Union has agreed to help Tunisia combat violent Islamic extremism and boost its economy, including by raising quotas on how much olive oil it can sell in EU markets.

entry.title: Tunisia tourism may be crippled by European warnings
entry.summary:
The blood on the sand has washed away, but the damage wreaked on Tunisia by a few terrifying minutes of gunfire at a beach resort will be deep and lasting.

Up to 2 million hotel nights are expected to be lost over the next year, hastened by warnings from Britain and other European governments last week that their citizens are no longer safe on Tunisia's shores.

"For work, we never get anything in Tunisia during the winter," he said.

entry.title: Tunisia says top terrorists killed
Top terrorists killed in Tunisia, minister says
entry.summary:
TUNIS, Tunisia -- Tunisia's interior minister said the government has killed an extremist leader and nearly wiped out his group, as European tourists continue to leave the country amid fears of new attacks.

Tunisia, the only country to succeed in building a democracy after Arab Spring uprisings, is trying to defuse criticism from Britain and others that it hasn't done enough to protect tourists.

The interior minister said the brigade was plotting attacks in Tunisia and sending Tunisians to fight jihad abroad.

entry.title: Tunisia deploys 100,000 security personnel to avert attacks
entry.summary: Tunisia's government says it has deployed 100,000 security personnel to protect the country and prevent new attacks, including 3,000 dedicated to protecting beaches, hotels and archaeological sites.

entry.title: Tunisia deploys 100,000 security personnel to avert attacks
Denmark tells its citizens not to travel to Tunisia
Tunisia defends efforts to protect foreign tourists
entry.summary: Ireland urged its citizens to leave if their presence in Tunisia was not essential.

entry.title: Tunisia says it's doing all it can to protect foreign tourists
entry.summary: Hundreds of thousands of Britons visit Tunisia each year.

entry.title: Tunis recoils, as Britain tells its citizens to flee Tunisia
entry.summary: The 30 Britons who died in Sousse were Thomson and First Choice customers and the operators - both owned by TUI Group - have no travelers in Tunisia.

entry.title: Tunisia Britons fly home after alert
entry.summary: Thomas Cook, which has cancelled all bookings to Tunisia until the October date, said it was putting on an extra flight on Friday to bring customers back to the UK.

entry.title: Tunisia defends efforts to protect British tourists
entry.summary: Tunisia's prime minister says that his country has done "everything in our power" to protect British and other foreign tourists, as British travelers flock to Tunisian airports under orders from their government to flee amid risks of terror attacks.

entry.title: Tunisia defends efforts to protect British tourists
entry.summary: Britain on Thursday told all U.K. tourists to leave Tunisia, saying the North African country hasn't done enough to enhance security.

entry.title: Tunisia defends efforts to protect British tourists
British government tells tourists: Leave Tunisia
entry.summary: In a statement, his office said the travel advice had been changed because "we do not believe the mitigation measures in place provide adequate protection for British tourists in Tunisia."

entry.title: U.K. tells tourists to leave Tunisia, says attack 'highly likely'
entry.summary: "If you're in Tunisia and you don't have an essential need to remain you should leave by commercial means," the statement said.

entry.title: Britain marking 10th anniversary of 7July bombings
entry.summary: He said: "The murder of 30 innocent Britons whilst holidaying in Tunisia is a brutal reminder of that fact. But we will never be cowed by terrorism."

entry.title: UK remembers 2005 London bombings under shadow of Tunisia
entry.summary: London (AFP) - Britain will on Tuesday mark 10 years since the London bombings with a minute's silence for the 52 victims, less than a fortnight after an attack in Tunisia highlighted the ongoing Islamist threat.

entry.title: Tunisia declares state of emergency after deadly beach hotel
entry.summary: With a nationwide televised address, President Beji Caid Essebsi officially reintroduced urgent security measures for Tunisia that had been lifted in March 2014.

entry.title: State of emergency declared in Tunisia
entry.summary: Tunisia's government has promised new laws to increase police powers and provide for harsher penalties for terrorism convictions.

entry.title: Tunisia imposes state of emergency after deadly beach attack
entry.summary:
Tunisia's state news agency says the country's president is declaring a state of emergency more than a week after a beach attack targeting foreign tourists that killed 38 people.

Tunisia's president declared a state of emergency on Saturday in response to a second deadly attack on foreigners in three months, saying the country is "not safe" and risks collapse from further extremist attacks.

entry.title: Tunisia imposes state of emergency after deadly beach attack
entry.summary: Tunisia was under a state of emergency from January 2011, at the outbreak of the Arab Spring, until March 2014.

entry.title: Tunisia President Declares State of Emergency
entry.summary: "Tunisia faces a very serious danger and it should take any possible measures to maintain security and safety," he said.

entry.title: Tunisia declares state of emergency
entry.summary: Mr Essebsi blamed the poor security in Libya for Tunisia's problems, and the lack of international resolve in targeting the Islamic State group throughout the region.
